newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Fighting with Palestinians hurts Israel tourism.
newsitem.headline: Fighting with Palestinians hurts Israel tourism.

text.p: New reservations from overseas tourists have come to a halt as a result of last week's bloody clashes between Palestinians and Israeli soldiers, Israel's Tourism Ministry said on Monday.
"This is the most worrying aspect," ministry spokeswoman Orly Doron said.
Tourism Minister Moshe Katzav convened an emergency meeting on Monday to discuss the situation in the wake of five days of fighting that killed 55 Palestinians and 14 Israelis.
The clashes were sparked by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's decision to open a tunnel near Moslem holy sites in Jerusalem.
The tourism ministry's deputy director general for marketing Shmuel Zurel told the meeting that there have not been cancellations for the short term.
But for the medium and long-term travel agents have cancelled allocations for hotels and flights that they block out for groups.
Representatives from the hotel sector said the full impact is not yet known as the reaction from abroad usually takes about three weeks to a month.
Zurel said the government meanwhile has halted a $6 million advertising campaign in Europe and the United States -- its biggest ever -- as a result of the events.
The United States has convened a Middle East summit in Washington this week in an attempt to restore peace between Israel and Palestinians.

"I hope that after a framework is set in Washington for continuing negotiations with the Palestinians, this positive message will be transmitted to the world and will benefit the economy and incoming tourism," Katzav was quoted as saying in a ministry statement.
